title: Styling glosses
text: default, glosses produced glossr don’t italics bold (may change future, user request). However, fairly easy adapt document level. formatting different lines stored options(), variables starting “glossr.format.”: glossr.format.preamble indicates styling (optional) first line, “source” variable rendered. glossr.format.indicates styling first gloss line. glossr.format.b indicates styling second gloss line. glossr.format.c indicates styling third gloss line. glossr.format.translation indicates styling translation line. options can either take value setting italics (“”, “”, “italics” “textit”) one setting boldface (“b” “bf”, “bold”, “textbf”). ’re familiar options(), can set preference entering something like chunk: Alternatively, use_glossr() offers friendlier interface wider variety names, can choose mnemonic works . argument “styling” must named list, key pointing line want style range values mentioned . source preamble valid names set format first optional line, source variable rendered. first valid names first gloss line. b second valid names second gloss line. c third valid names third gloss line. ft, trans translation valid names free translation line. like add alternatives, let know! example, run following chunk: …set first lines italics sources boldface. next one, hand: …set first line free translation italics. can always annul setting typing options(glossr.format.= NULL), example. set-meant encourage/enforce keep style across given file.
code: options(glossr.format.a = "i") # italics in the first line library(glossr) use_glossr(styling = list(   source = "b",   first = "i" )) use_glossr(styling = list(   first = "i",   trans = "i" ))

title: Styling glosses
text: Next line formatting options, styling argument can take two elements. First, “trans_quotes” (also set options(glossr.trans.quotes = "whatever")) defines character want surround translation . default, double quotes, might want select single quotes instead, remove altogether. following chunk code sets italics first line single quotes translation: following removes quotes altogether: Finally, “par_spacing” (also set options(glossr.par.spacing = 0)) defines space glosses PDF output, default 0. Depending settings template, might want add spacing.
code: use_glossr(styling = list(   first = "i",   trans_quotes = "'" )) use_glossr(styling = list(   first = "i",   trans_quotes = "" ))
